Award.AwardTitle: Ocean Acidification-Category 3- Third Symposium on The Ocean in a High-CO2 World
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

The Scientific Committee on Oceanic Research (SCOR), Intergovernmental Oceanographic Commission (IOC) of UNESCO, and International Geosphere - Biosphere Programme (IGBP) have formed an international committee to plan the Third Symposium on The Ocean in a High-CO2 World. The third symposium will (1) provide a forum for the global community of scientists studying ocean acidification to share their research results through oral and poster presentations; (2) identify priority research topics and approaches for international collaboration through discussion groups; (3) create a summary of the latest research results for policymakers, and (4) create a special issue of a peer-reviewed journal and a scientific summary to disseminate the results of the symposium to the broader ocean science community and make the results available for assessments such as that of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. The symposium will be hosted by a consortium of institutions in Monterey, California in autumn 2012. The planning committee will consider topics identified by national research communities, such as the priority areas identified by NSF through responses to its solicitation of first-year Ocean Acidification proposals- molecular/cellular, high latitude, and paleoceanographic aspects of ocean acidification - and priorities identified by the National Research Council report Ocean Acidification: A National Strategy to Meet the Challenges of a Changing Ocean. Funding will emphasize support for early career scientists, students and scientists from under-represented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant was awarded to plan and convene an international symposium on The Ocean in a High-CO2 World, the third in a series of symposiums on the topic of ocean acidification. The number of scientists studying this area of ocean science has grown substantially worldwide since the first symposium in 2004, so that more than 600 individuals from 33 nations attended the symposium in Monterey, California in September 2012 that was partially funded by this grant. One hundred seventy-one early-career scientists--graduate students, post-doctoral fellows, and assistant professors--participated in the symposium and most made oral and poster presentations.  A significant portion of the grant (40%) was devoted to providing partial support to early-career scientists, and special mentoring and networking activities were provided to these individuals.

Overall, 10 invited plenary lectures were given, along with 135 oral presentations and more than 200 poster presentations selected among the abstracts submitted. The scientific presentations spanned three days and covered a wide range of topics. The greatest uncertainties and the most research being conducted concern the effects of ocean acidification on individual organisms and ecosystems; the concentration of presentations in these topic areas reflected the importance of such research. The oral and poster presentations were distributed among the following topics: responses of marine organisms and ecosystems to multiple environmental stressors; ecosystem change and resilience in response to ocean acidification; acclimation and adaptation to ocean acidification: genomics, physiology, and behavior; biogeochemical consequences of ocean acidification and feedbacks to the Earth system; interactions of ocean acidification with physical climate change; effects of ocean acidification on calcifying organisms; changes in the oceanic carbonate system from the paleorecord to present; the social science implications of ocean acidification; detection and attribution of ocean acidification changes and effects; Impacts of ocean acidification on food webs and fisheries, regional impacts of ocean acidification; and new concerns in ocean acidification research. An important feature of this symposium was a greater amount of research presented on multiple factors stressing organisms at the same time, such as the combined effects of decreased pH and increased temperature and/or decreased oxygen. The symposium also included a greater number of presentations on the ecosystem effects of ocean acidification and on socioeconomic impacts of ocean acidification, compared with previous symposiums.

Following the three science days, a "Policy Day" presented a summary of the science from the first three days, as well as presenting viewpoints on ocean acidification as a public policy issue. Prominent leaders, such as Prince Albert II of Monaco and U.S. Congressman Sam Farr, were joined by Dr. Jane Lubchenco, the Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, Bill Dewey, a commercial oyster farmer, and media representatives and scientists to discuss the need for better information about the effects of ocean acidification and means to reduce and mitigate its effects.
